issues.text: whether the High Court was, in the circumstances of the case, competent to appraise the evidence after discarding the verdict of the jury and to confirm the sentence of death after modifying the order of conviction

anchor.surface_text: The first question that falls to be determined is whether the High Court was, in the circumstances of the case, competent to appraise the evidence after discarding the verdict of the jury and to confirm the sentence of death after modifying the order of conviction. Section 423 of the Code of Criminal Procedure invests the High Court hearing on appeal against an order of conviction

issues.text: whether the trial has been vitiated [due to irregularities in the examination of the accused under s. 342 CrPC]

anchor.surface_text: Errors of this type fall within the category of curable irregularities and the question whether the trial has been vitiated depends in each case upon the degree of error and upon whether prejudice has been or is likely to have been caused to the accused.

issues.text: whether the prosecution has established the guilt of the appellants on the evidence

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contend that they were not responsible for the injuries to these victims. We were taken through the entire evidence which is material to the case of the three appellants by the learned counsel for the appellants.

arguments.claim: High Court is bound to order retrial when jury verdict is vitiated in death sentence confirmation proceedings combined with appeal

anchor.surface_text: But it is contended that where the Court of Session in a trial held by jury sentences the accused to suffer the penalty of death and the case is submitted to the High Court under s. 374 of the Code of Criminal Procedure for confirmation of sentence and the accused also appeals against the order of conviction and sentence, the High Court is bound to hear and decide the appeal in the first instance, and if on a consideration of the appeal, the High Court holds that the verdict was vitiated on account of misdirection or misunderstanding of the law on the part of the Jury, the verdict must be set aside and with the disappearance of the verdict disappears the order of sentence, and it is not open to the High Court to confirm the sentence of death on a reappraisal of the evidence. The High Court is bound in these cases, says counsel for the appellants to order retrial of the accused.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t may for example acquit the accused. To order a retrial might well operate injustice in readily companyceivable circumstances. We are therefore of th

arguments.court_reasoning: s.374 and s.376 give wide powers to HC independent of appeal; must independently assess guilt even in jury trials; not bound to order retrial.

arguments.claim: No proper trial before Sessions Court due to irregular examination under s.342 CrPC; trial vitiated and retrial must be ordered

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants, contended that in this case there had been no proper trial of the appellants before the Court of Session and therefore the order of the High Court should be set aside and retrial ordered. Counsel strongly relied upon the manner in which the examination of the accused under s. 342 by the Court of Session was conducted and submitted that the Sessions Judge asked complex questions to each of the accused relating to several distinct pieces of evidence brought on the record.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r true or is companysistent with his innocence. The opportunity must be real and adequate. Questions must be so framed as to give to the accused clear

arguments.court_reasoning: Irregularity curable unless prejudice shown; no prejudice as denials given and no alternative explanation suggested; not raised in HC.

arguments.claim: Prosecution evidence unreliable due to delay in sending FIR copy to Magistrate indicating fabrication

court_response_anchor.surface_text: round of utter improbability unreliable. It was urged that the numbermal reaction of an assailant running away from the scene of offence to escape arr

arguments.court_reasoning: Delay alone does not discredit direct evidence without proof of fabrication; mere endorsement date insufficient against mass of direct evidence.

arguments.claim: Story of Bimala carrying knife when arrested is improbable as assailant would discard weapon

anchor.surface_text: It was then urged that the story that Bimala was carrying a knife even when she was arrested was on the ground of utter improbability unreliable. It was urged that the normal reaction of an assailant running away from the scene of offence to escape arrest would be to throw away the weapon of offence.

arguments.court_reasoning: Argument based on mere improbability insufficient against body of disinterested testimony.

anchor.surface_text: It was also submitted that the story of Jadunandan Roy that he caught Sudama Singh after the latter had stabbed Shyama Prosad Missir is untrue. It was urged that if Sudama Singh, who was armed with a knife was over-powered by Jadunandan Roy, the story that Sudama Singh ran away with the other assailants could not be true.

arguments.claim: Acquittal of Ramnarayan and Depali discredits prosecution witnesses who placed them at scene

arguments.court_reasoning: No evidence Depali participated in assault; Ramnarayan presence but no reliable participation evidence; does not discredit evidence against appellants.

anchor.surface_text: In the cross-examination of these witnesses for the prosecution, it was suggested that there was a free fight between some Hindusthanis and goalas, in the course of which injuries may have been suffered by Rampiari, Hiralal, Shyama Prosad Missir and Suraj Dubey.

arguments.court_reasoning: Victims in own room or specific spots; no injuries on accused side; no evidence Hindusthanis assaulted victims.

arguments.claim: Evidence against Sudama Singh insufficient: no residence nearby, no blood on clothes/knife

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants submitted that, in any event, against Sudama Singh the evidence was not strong enough to warrant his conviction. It was contended that Sudama Singh resides not in Madhab Ghosh Road but in the godown in which he was arrested. It is also urged that no extensive blood marks were found on his clothes and the knife alleged to have been used by him is not found.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the incident found the door of Ramdeo Ahirs room broken and blood marks were found at various places in Ramdeo Ahirs room as well as in the companyrt

arguments.court_reasoning: Mass of reliable eyewitnesses; corroborated by other witnesses seeing him with knife, blood on dhoti, arrest.

arguments.claim: HC competent under s.423 CrPC to appraise evidence and deal with appeal even after discarding vitiated jury verdict without retrial

anchor.surface_text: Section 423 of the Code of Criminal Procedure invests the High Court hearing on appeal against an order of conviction or acquittal passed by a Subordinate court of criminal jurisdiction with certain powers. These powers are exerciseable in appeals against orders passed in proceedings which are tried with or without the aid of jury.

arguments.claim: In death sentence confirmation under s.374/376 CrPC, HC must independently appraise evidence regardless of jury verdict

anchor.surface_text: Irrespective of whether the accused who is sentenced to death prefers an appeal, the High Court is bound to consider the evidence and arrive at an independent conclusion as to the guilt or innocence of the accused and this the High Court must do even if the trial of the accused was held by jury.

arguments.claim: s.342 irregularity is curable unless prejudice to accused shown

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the learned Sessions judge in rolling up several distinct matters of evidence in a single question acted irregularly... every error or omission in complying with s. 342 does not vitiate the trial. Errors of this type fall within the category of curable irregularities.

arguments.claim: Prosecution evidence sufficient to prove guilt beyond doubt; eyewitnesses reliable, corroborated

anchor.surface_text: We were taken through the entire evidence which is material to the case of the three appellants by the learned counsel for the appellants... On a review of the evidence, we hold that the First Information about the commission of the offence was given immediately... Having regard to these circumstances, we are of the view that the High Court was right in holding that the prosecution story was true.

arguments.claim: Jury trial right statutory, not absolute; HC discretion to reappraise or retrial after vitiation

anchor.surface_text: The right of trial by jury is an important right conferred upon accused persons in the trial of certain serious offences but under our jurisprudence the right to trial by jury is a creation of statute and the question whether the accused in a given case having had the benefit of a trial by jury should because of misdirection be ordered to be retried, or his case be considered on the evidence by the appellate court, is one of the discretion and not of right.

arguments.claim: Precedent in Abdul Rahim v. Emperor supports HC maintaining conviction after excluding inadmissible evidence without retrial

anchor.surface_text: In Abdul Rahim v. Emperor (1946) L.R. 73 I.A. 77, in dealing with the powers of a High Court in a reference under s. 374 for confirmation of death sentence passed by the Court of Session in a trial held with jury, where the verdict of the jury was found to be vitiated on the ground of admission of evidence, which, in law, was inadmissible, the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council observed Where inadmissible evidence has been admitted in trial by jury, the High Court on appeal may, after excluding such evidence, maintain a conviction, provided the admissible evidence remaining is in the opinion of the Court sufficient to establish the guilt of the accused.

arguments.claim: Bhupati Bhusan Biswas precedent: HC should reappraise evidence rather than order retrial in some cases

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the State invited our attention to judgment of this Court in Bhupati Bhusan Biswas v. The State of West Bengal Cr. A. 113 of 1956, decided on February 14, 1957, in which this Court set aside the order passed by High Court directing retrial of a case which was tried with jury, in which the verdict was vitiated, and ordered that the High Court should hear the case on the evidence.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ces, the sentence of death was the appropriate sentence. The High Court is of companyrse companypete

holdings.text: s. 423 applies to all appeals before the High Court whether from a trial by jury or otherwise and when the High Court finds that the verdict of the jury is vitiated on account of some defect of law or misdirection it has full power to deal with the appeal in the manner specified in s. 423 and for that purpose it may appraise the evidence to decide what course it will follow.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that s. 423 applies to all appeals before the High Court whether from a trial by jury or otherwise and when the High Court finds that the verdict of the jury is vitiated on account of some defect of law or misdirection it has full power to deal with the appeal in the manner specified in s. 423 and for that purpose it may appraise the evidence to decide what course it will follow.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets s.423 powers applicable to jury trials; allows appraisal and various orders upon vitiation without mandatory retrial; supported by statutory text and Privy Council precedent.

holdings.text: Irrespective of whether the accused who is sentenced to death prefers an appeal, the High Court is bound to consider the evidence and arrive at an independent conclusion as to the guilt or innocence of the accused and this the High Court must do even if the trial of the accused was held by jury.

anchor.surface_text: Irrespective of whether the accused who is sentenced to death prefers an appeal, the High Court is bound to consider the evidence and arrive at an independent conclusion as to the guilt or innocence of the accused and this the High Court must do even if the trial of the accused was held by jury.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.374/376 mandate independent evidence review in death confirmations overriding jury verdict; uniform High Court practice.

holdings.text: The High Court is competent when dealing with a reference under s. 374 to order a retrial but the High Court is not bound to do so in every case tried with jury when the verdict of the jury is found to be vitiated because of error of law or misdirection.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court is of course competent when dealing with a reference under s. 374 to order a retrial but the High Court is not bound to do so in every case tried with jury when the verdict of the jury is found to be vitiated because of error of law or misdirection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide discretionary powers under s.376; no absolute retrial obligation; discretion properly exercised here.

holdings.text: The right of trial by jury is an important right conferred upon accused persons in the trial of certain serious offences but under our jurisprudence the right to trial by jury is a creation of statute and the question whether the accused in a given case having had the benefit of a trial by jury should because of misdirection be ordered to be retried, or his case be considered on the evidence by the appellate court, is one of the discretion and not of right.

anchor.surface_text: The right of trial by jury is an important right conferred upon accused persons in the trial of certain serious offences but under our jurisprudence the right to trial by jury is a creation of statute and the question whether the accused in a given case having had the benefit of a trial by jury should because of misdirection be ordered to be retried, or his case be considered on the evidence by the appellate court, is one of the discretion and not of right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory origin limits jury right; appellate discretion to reappraise vs retrial.

holdings.text: every error or omission in complying with s. 342 does not vitiate the trial. Errors of this type fall within the category of curable irregularities and the question whether the trial has been vitiated depends in each case upon the degree of error and upon whether prejudice has been or is likely to have been caused to the accused.

anchor.surface_text: Errors of this type fall within the category of curable irregularities and the question whether the trial has been vitiated depends in each case upon the degree of error and upon whether prejudice has been or is likely to have been caused to the accused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.342 mandatory but non-compliance curable absent prejudice; no prejudice shown here as denials given and no alternative explanation possible.

holdings.text: In the present case, we are of the view, having regard to the circumstances, that the appellants have not been prejudiced, because of failure to examine them strictly in compliance of the terms of s. 342 of the Code

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, we are of the view, having regard to the circumstances, that the appellants have not been prejudiced, because of failure to examine them strictly in compliance of the terms of s. 342 of the Code and that view is strengthened by the fact that the plea was not raised in the High Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: No prejudice from lumped questions; complete denials given; plea not raised earlier; cross-examination shows no other explanation available.

holdings.text: On a review of the evidence, we hold that the First Information about the commission of the offence was given immediately... Having regard to these circumstances, we are of the view that the High Court was right in holding that the prosecution story was true.

anchor.surface_text: On a review of the evidence, we hold that the First Information about the commission of the offence was given immediately in the First Information the names of the three appellants and the part played by them was set out in detail. The police officer who arrived on the scene shortly after the incident found the door of Ramdeo Ahirs room broken and blood marks were found at various places in Ramdeo Ahirs room as well as in the courtyard.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Eyewitnesses reliable/numerous/disinterested; corroborated by FIR, medical, recoveries; rejects improbabilities, delays, free fight theory.

holdings.text: Sudama Singh was present at the scene of offence and he broke open the door of Ramdeo Ahirs house to facilitate the entry of Ram Shankar and Bimala to murder Rampiari and Hiralal and that he stabbed Shyama Prosad Missir with a knife.

anchor.surface_text: having regard to the evidence of the eye-witnesses, which is both independent and disinterested, we see no reason to disagree with the view of the High Court that Sudama Singh was present at the scene of offence and he broke open the door of Ramdeo Ahirs house to facilitate the entry of Ram Shankar and Bimala to murder Rampiari and Hiralal and that he stabbed Shyama Prosad Missir with a knife.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Multiple eyewitnesses; additional corroboration from hearing arrival, seeing with knife, blood on dhoti, arrest.

holdings.text: There is no ground, therefore, for disagreeing with the High Court that this is pre-eminently a case in which death sentence should be imposed on the three appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Shankar and Bimala forceably entered the house of Ramdeo Ahir and killed Rampiari and Hiralal. Ram Shankar also stabbed Suraj Dubey when he attempted to protest against his conduct. Sudama Singh, besides breaking open the door of Ramdeo Ahirs room to facilitate the entry by Ram Shankar and Bimala stabbed Shyama Prosad Missir when the latter tried to intervene. The assault upon the members of the family of Ramdeo Ahir was conceived and initiated with deliberation, and with the object of slaughtering a defenceless woman and her young son. Innocent persons who intervened were mercilessly stabbed and killed. There is no ground, therefore, for disagreeing with the High Court that this is pre-eminently a case in which death sentence should be imposed on the three appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deliberate slaughter of defenseless victims and interveners; affirms HC death sentences.

precedents.citation: Abdul Rahim v. Emperor  1946  L.R. 73 I.A. 77

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants does number challenge this interpretation of the powers of the High Court under ss. 418 and 423 of the Code. In Abdul Rahim v. Emperor  1946  L.R. 73 I.A. 77, in dealing with the powers of a High Court in a reference under s. 374 for companyfirmation of death sentence passed by the Court of Session in a trial held with jury, where the verdict of the jury was found to be vitiated on the ground of admission of evidence, which, in law, was inadmissible, the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council observed

precedents.cited_proposition: In a jury trial where inadmissible evidence is admitted or there is misdirection, the High Court on appeal may exclude such evidence and maintain conviction if remaining admissible evidence suffices, without being bound to order retrial
precedents.cited_holding: Where inadmissible evidence has been admitted in trial by jury, the High Court on appeal may, after excluding such evidence, maintain a companyviction, provided the admissible evidence remaining is in the opinion of the Court sufficient to establish the guilt of the accused. The High Court is number bound to order retrial in such cases.

precedents.citation: Bhupati Bhusan Biswas v. The State of West Bengal Cr. A. 113 of 1956, decided on February 14, 1957

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the State invited our attention to judgment of this Court in Bhupati Bhusan Biswas v. The State of West Bengal Cr. A. 113 of 1956, decided on February 14, 1957, in which this Court set aside the order passed by High Court directing retrial of a case which was tried with jury, in which the verdict was vitiated, and ordered that the High Court should hear the case on the evidence. The Court in that case observed,

precedents.case_name: Bhupati Bhusan Biswas v. The State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court should examine the evidence itself rather than ordering retrial when jury verdict is vitiated, following Privy Council procedure
precedents.cited_holding: In the circumstances of this case we are of the opinion that the High Court was in error in remanding the case for retrial it should have followed the procedure laid down in the Privy Council case and should have gone into the evidence and determined for itself whether the accused were guilty or number.

precedents.citation: Ajmer Singh State of Punjab 1953 S.C.R. 418

anchor.surface_text: This Court pointed out in Ajmer Singh State of Punjab 1953 S.C.R. 418, that it is number a sufficient companypliance with the section  s. 342 Code of Criminal Procedure  to generally ask the accused that, having heard the prosecution evidence what he has to say about it. He must be questioned separately about each material circumstance which is intended to be used against him. The whole object of the section is to afford the accused a fair and proper opportunity of explaining circumstances which appear against him and the questions must be fair and must be couched in a form which an ignorant or illiterate person may be able to appreciate and understand.

precedents.case_name: Ajmer Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Examination of accused under s.342 CrPC requires questioning separately about each material circumstance; general question insufficient, but every error or omission does not vitiate the trial unless prejudice caused
precedents.cited_holding: it is number a sufficient companypliance with the section s. 342 Code of Criminal Procedure to generally ask the accused that, having heard the prosecution evidence what he has to say about it. He must be questioned separately about each material circumstance which is intended to be used against him.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that s. 423 applies to all appeals before the High Court whether from a trial by jury or otherwise and when the High Court finds that the verdict of the jury is vitiated on account of some defect of law or misdirection it has full power to deal with the appeal in the manner specified in s. 423 and for that purpose it may appraise the evidence to decide what course it will follow.
There is no ground, therefore, for disagreeing with the High Court that this is pre-eminently a case in which death sentence should be imposed on the three appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Irrespective of whether the accused who is sentenced to death prefers an appeal, the High Court is bound to consider the evidence and arrive at an independent conclusion as to the guilt or innocence of the accused and this the High Court must do even if the trial of the accused was held by jury.
There is no ground, therefore, for disagreeing with the High Court that this is pre-eminently a case in which death sentence should be imposed on the three appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court is of course competent when dealing with a reference under s. 374 to order a retrial but the High Court is not bound to do so in every case tried with jury when the verdict of the jury is found to be vitiated because of error of law or misdirection.
There is no ground, therefore, for disagreeing with the High Court that this is pre-eminently a case in which death sentence should be imposed on the three appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The right of trial by jury is an important right conferred upon accused persons in the trial of certain serious offences but under our jurisprudence the right to trial by jury is a creation of statute and the question whether the accused in a given case having had the benefit of a trial by jury should because of misdirection be ordered to be retried, or his case be considered on the evidence by the appellate court, is one of the discretion and not of right.
There is no ground, therefore, for disagreeing with the High Court that this is pre-eminently a case in which death sentence should be imposed on the three appellants.

anchor.surface_text: On a review of the evidence, we hold that the First Information about the commission of the offence was given immediately in the First Information the names of the three appellants and the part played by them was set out in detail. The police officer who arrived on the scene shortly after the incident found the door of Ramdeo Ahirs room broken and blood marks were found at various places in Ramdeo Ahirs room as well as in the courtyard.
There is no ground, therefore, for disagreeing with the High Court that this is pre-eminently a case in which death sentence should be imposed on the three appellants.
